subject: Re: [junit] Parsing Junit test results
msgSnippet: Hi Jeff, Though this is an old reply, I was revisiting to find if the above code could help me in my requirement. I tried to implement into my testcodes, but
messageBody:
Hi Jeff,

Though this is an old reply, I was revisiting to find if the above code
could help me in my requirement.

I tried to implement into my testcodes, but it seems that the parameter
startTest(Test t) gets a Junit Test class name :
simply put :. public void startTest(Test t)
where Test t always remains junit.extensions.jfunc.TestletWrapper
where i want name of the TestClass like AbcXyz.testAddString(String a ,String b)

Could suggest what changes i do make to get this type of result.

Thanks in adv.




Jeff Nielsen wrote:

> This behavior of XMLJUnitResultFormatter also bothered me. Below is the
> extension to this class that I wrote, so that the results would include the
> name of the TestCase in addition to the name of the test method. So you get
> "FooTest(testBar)" rather than just "testBar".
>
> Jeff Nielsen
> Digital Focus
>
> =========================================================
>
> .import java.util.Hashtable;
> .import java.lang.reflect.Field;
> .import junit.framework.*;
> .import org.w3c.dom.Element;
> .import org.w3c.dom.Document;
> .import
> org.apache.tools.ant.taskdefs.optional.junit.XMLJUnitResultFormatter;
> .
> .public class DfXmlJunitResultFormatter extends XMLJUnitResultFormatter {
> .
> . /** Override this method to include the name of the test class */
> . public void startTest(Test t) {
> . Document theDoc = (Document) getField("doc");
> . Element theRootElement = (Element) getField("rootElement");
> . Hashtable theTestStarts = (Hashtable) getField("testStarts");
> . Hashtable theTestElements = (Hashtable) getField("testElements");
> .
> . theTestStarts.put(t, new Long(System.currentTimeMillis()));
> . Element currentTest = theDoc.createElement(TESTCASE);
> .
> . String name = t.getClass().getName();
> . if (t instanceof TestCase) {
> . TestCase tc = (TestCase) t;
> . name = tc.getName() + "(" + name + ")";
> . }
> .
> . currentTest.setAttribute(ATTR_NAME, name);
> . theRootElement.appendChild(currentTest);
> . theTestElements.put(t, currentTest);
> . }
> .
> . /** Hack to get access to private fields in superclass */
> . private Object getField(String fieldName) {
> . try {
> . Field f =
> XMLJUnitResultFormatter.class.getDeclaredField(fieldName);
> . f.setAccessible(true);
> . return f.get(this);
> . } catch (Exception e) {
> . e.printStackTrace();
> . return null;
> . }
> . }
> .}
>
> =========================================================
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Ranjeet Sahay" <rsahay@...>
> To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Monday, August 25, 2003 10:45 AM
> Subject: Re: [junit] Parsing Junit test results
>
> > Hi,
> >
> > Very much agree with Larry. I have a peculiar problem on similar lines.
> > I have created test suites (say A,B,C ) and again added these to new test
> suite (say D)
> > to make it a Regression Test Driver.
> >
> > When i run through junit ant task, all my Test classes (extending JFunc)
> are
> > instantiated and tests executed.
> > However, the result with JUnit Report shows results of only test methods
> > executed, and has no association from the original Test Class which it
> belongs to.
> > In short the presentation of report is such that all test
> methods(containing asserts)
> > belong to Test Class containing suite ( D as above) .
> >
> > Any Other Good idea to associated them to Test classes which they belong.
> > I already know to
> > 1. Run Test Classes individually
> > 2. use Batchtest ant task
> > to achive the desired result -- But NEED fresh idea.
> >
> > Thanks
> >
> > Ranjeet Sahay
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > "Tambascio, Larry" wrote:
> >
> > > Hey Nikunj,
> > >
> > > The junit Ant task can capture all the results in an XML file(s). The
> > > junitreport ant task, I believe, does an XSL transformation of that XML.
> > > I'm willing to bet that the XML file which has the results has enough
> > > information for you to do your processing. You could write your own
> custom
> > > Ant task, based on junitreport if you like, to do the processing of the
> > > results you desire. You could do your own XSL transformation, or you
> could
> > > simply parse through the file with some XML parser extracting that which
> you
> > > need.
> > >
> > > I would urge you to look at what the junit ant task outputs in the XML
> file.
> > > It captures results, so why rewrite it? Sounds like you have some
> pretty
> > > specific things you want to do with the results, and what those are
> isn't
> > > exactly clear.
> > >
> > > Hope this helps,
> > > -Larry
> > >
> > > -----Original Message-----
> > > From: Nikunj Manocha [mailto:manochanikunj@...]
> > > Sent: Thursday, August 21, 2003 11:04 AM
> > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > Subject: [junit] Parsing Junit test results
> > >
> > > Hi All,
> > >
> > > My application needs the following:
> > > 1. Execute a suite of junit tests
> > > 2. Parse the results and identify certain critical test results
> > > 3. If the test pass, then carry forward with processing otherwise
> > > kill.
> > >
> > > I am looking for ideas or applications that would allow me to parse
> > > the result. How could this best be done? Any ideas would be
> > > appreciated since I have never used this before and am looking for
> > > options to do this prasing. I am working with Ant scripts to execute
> > > JUnit on a Unix environment.
> > >
> > > Thanx for your help.
> > >
> > > Regards,
> > > Nikunj
> > >
